While in Computer Science theory accessing a Map is faster than iterating through an array, in practice it may be a different story. Would you consider running a benchmark for various sizes (100, 1_000, 10_000, 1_000_000) between 3 different implementations:
1. The original that uses the handlers array and the find() function
2. Your proposed on with the usage of a Map
3. Another one with a plain Object, similar to how the Map is used

The rationale behind these is:
1. For small sizes arrays in practice should be faster, since they utilize a continuous block of memory plus we do not allocate a new object or Map for the Garbage collector to clean up later.
2. V8 may optimize the Object and Map approaches differently based on their sizes/contents (e.g. if Object has messages of similar structure)

Based on the above and its findings, it may be worth it to have an approach where we switch between implementations based on the size itself.

Thanks!
Very valuable advice! I will find time to experiment and make further optimizations.

Hey @CodyTseng , great work on testing this out! 

I believe that the original implementation based on the Map is going to serve well this implementation, since it is a sizeable improvement over using an array. Resolving to an object for larger data sizes is a minor improvement IMHO, since data should be flushed at that point and not hold that many concurrent messages, unless people try to handle a lot of traffic on a single service instance.

Let me know of your thoughts on this.

Thanks!
Generally, the number of message handlers does not exceed 100. With this quantity, the performance of the Map is optimal, providing a 5 to 10 times improvement compared to using an Array.

Why not filter + map? Performance should be marginal in this case (I'd think)

To use `.map`, I will also need to use `.filter`.  So I didn't want to introduce two loops, that's why I use `for`.

About the performance, if this method is called often, someone will eventually create a pull request to change `filter` and `map` to a for loop, so I prefer to not introduce a point of optimization in the future if we can do it now.
Still, the performance impact should be negligible. filter & map is just cleaner & easier to read, not worth the optimization in this particular case

Instead I change `map + filter` to `reduce` which I think is a middle ground between readability and performance.

About the performance:

```
MetadataScanner#scanFromPrototype x 109,945 ops/sec Â±1.63% (88 runs sampled)
BetterMetadataScanner#scanFromPrototype map and filter x 232,174 ops/sec Â±2.00% (86 runs sampled)
BetterMetadataScanner#scanFromPrototype reduce x 244,521 ops/sec Â±1.50% (89 runs sampled)
BetterMetadataScanner#scanFromPrototype for loop x 246,414 ops/sec Â±1.39% (88 runs sampled)
Fastest is BetterMetadataScanner#scanFromPrototype for loop,BetterMetadataScanner#scanFromPrototype reduce
```

If you're going to refactor this to a raw for loop, we should do the same to the `getAll` for squeezing as much performance out as we can. 

Side note: do you have any benchmarks for how much of an improvement this is? Just curious if the improvement is going to be worth the readability
I think raw for loop is not the mainly reason. Just break the loop earlier to increase the performance.
